name: LED Blinking with 555 Timer
shortDescription: A classic beginner project to make an LED flash using a 555 timer IC.
theory: The 555 timer operates in astable mode, producing a square wave output that turns the LED on and off at a regular interval determined by the resistors and capacitor.
steps: Place the 555 timer on the breadboard.
Connect pin 1 to Ground (GND).
Connect pin 8 to VCC (9V).
Connect pin 4 to VCC.
Connect the 10uF capacitor between pin 2 and Ground.
Connect pin 2 to pin 6.
Connect the 10k resistor between pin 7 and VCC.
Connect the 1k resistor between pin 7 and pin 6.
Connect the LED anode to pin 3 and cathode to Ground via a resistor.

name: 5V Regulated Power Supply
shortDescription: Convert 9V or 12V DC to a stable 5V DC output using the 7805 regulator.
theory: The 7805 voltage regulator IC takes a higher input voltage and maintains a constant 5V output, which is essential for powering many digital circuits.
steps: Place the 7805 regulator on the breadboard.
Connect the Input pin (1) to the positive terminal of the battery.
Connect the Ground pin (2) to the negative terminal.
Connect the 100uF capacitor between Input and Ground.
Connect the 10uF capacitor between Output (3) and Ground.
Measure the voltage across Output and Ground to verify 5V.

name: LDR Automatic Street Light
shortDescription: Turns on an LED automatically when it gets dark using a Light Dependent Resistor.
theory: An LDR changes its resistance based on light intensity. When used in a voltage divider circuit with a transistor, it can switch a load (LED) on or off depending on ambient light.
steps: Place the BC547 transistor on the breadboard.
Connect the emitter to Ground.
Connect the LDR between the base and VCC.
Connect the 10k resistor between the base and Ground.
Connect the LED anode to VCC via the 330 ohm resistor.
Connect the LED cathode to the collector of the transistor.
